results.title: Being True Blue
results.creator_credit: Kay Donovan, Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This documentary explores what it means to be an Australian citizen and just what a new citizen is welcome to. In interviews with historians, social planners and ordinary people, ‘Being True Blue’ looks behind the facade of the national anthem, the sports hero, the bushman and the other cheap barometers of identity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kay Donovan, Australia. Office of Multicultural Affairs and SBS-TV

results.title: Being there
results.creator_credit: Hal Ashby, Andrew Braunsberg, United Artists Corporation and Lorimar Film Entertainment
results.brief_description: Chauncey Gardener is a feeble-minded gardener whose life is centred on watching television. When his benefactor dies he is let loose on a world of which he cannot make sense, and which he cannot change with the remote control. An accident brings him into contact with Washington diplomats and business people and the inanities Chauncey learned from television sound like profundities to them. Soon he has met the U.S. President and Chauncey is on his way to ruling the world. This little gem of a movie, with its savage black comedy and cynical perspective on U.S. politics was released on the eve of Reagan’s election to President. With Peter Sellers, Shirley MacLaine and Melvyn Douglas. Based on the book by Jerzy Kosinski.

results.title: Being right: can you still lose?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Questions, Answers.”.
An excerpt from the feature ” Ride a wild pony”, which has an Australian setting. Conflict flares when two children claim ownership of a wild pony. A judge settles the dispute by allowing the pony to decide. The film centres on how the children cope with the decision. The aim of the film is to allow children to explore the concepts of winning and losing and how to deal with them. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Being real about relationships
results.creator_credit: Laurie Tesoriero, Betti Wood, Family Film Movement and Pilgrim Films
results.brief_description: In the second half of the Twentieth Century there have been developments in contraception. The film explains the rhythm, the calender, the temperature, the ovulation, the withdrawal, the barrier, the diaphragm, the condom, the IUD, the pill and the sterilisation methods.

results.title: Being positive
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Heather Ellis
results.brief_description: A sensitive and warmly told story by Heather Ellis, mother and wife, diagnosed HIV positive in 1997 upon returning to Australia from a trip to Africa. Heather’s greatest fear is the stigma which may be attached to her son Ethan who is HIV negative but yet she feels privileged that medication is available in Australia for recovery and prevention of positive babies being born. In Africa they do not have this privilege.

results.title: Being me
results.creator_credit: Keryn James, Susan Redden and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Being Me is an ABC health series for students in middle to upper primary school years, that “encourages kids to know themselves, like themselves and be themselves” (ABC). The eight twenty minute episodes are made in a style designed to engage children, with the use of vibrant colour and sound, numerous dramatisations, short comic skits featuring the superhero “Bounce Back Man”, recurring “Kid’s News” segments, and group discussions amongst school children. Presenter Alex Shepherd ties together and summarises the themes and strategies explored in each program. Episode 1 “Identity” looks at issues of individual identity, including how it is constructed and expressed; Episode 2 “Happy to Be Me” deals with self esteem. Episode 3 “Belonging” explores the dynamics of group affiliations and interactions; Episode 4 “Making Friends” investigates why and how we make friends; Episode 5 “Keeping Friends” examines how friendship is maintained in the face of everyday challenges such as arguments. Episode 6 “Power and Responsibility” delves into issues of responsibility and power in relationships, and examines the affects of bullying and other abuses of that power. Episode 7 “Changes” considers change as a normal and ongoing, if challenging, part of life; Episode 8 “Taking Risks” analyses how taking risks can be a necessary part of growing, and looks at how to assess and mitigate risks.

results.title: Being male
results.creator_credit: Don White, George Johnson, John Taylor and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: One effect of the women’s movement in western societies has been the gradual realization by some males that they are also trapped by stereotypes. In this film, sixteen- and seventeen-year-old boys talk candidly about how the traditional image of maleness fits their own experience. Young men, the film shows, are beginning to re-evaluate their role in society.

results.title: Being John Malkovich [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Spike Jonze, Vincent Landay, Steve Golin, Sandy Stern, Michael Stipe, Propaganda Films and PolyGram
results.brief_description: Being John Malkovich is without a doubt one of the more surreal and original films to come out of America for some time. The inspired plot goes something like this, Craig Schwartz, a down on his luck puppeteer (John Cusack) takes on a filing job in a building on the 7 1/2 (the explanation why it’s 7 1/2 is hilarious). There, he encounters the sexy and cruel Maxine (Catherine Keener), whom he immediately forms an unhealthy attraction for, unbeknown to his timid and devoted wife, Lotte (an unrecognizable Cameron Diaz). Things get strange however when Craig discovers a small doorway at the back of a filing cabinet which ends up being a portal into John Malkovich’s mind. This of course is only the beginning. Director Spike Jonze, whose background is in music video’s (Beastie Boy’s “Sabotage” and Fat Boy Slim’s “Praise You” just to name a few) has opted to treat the film’s insane subject matter in the most matter of fact way. The screenplay by Charlie Kaufman explores every possibility that this existential conundrum evokes, at turns managing to be hilarious, weird and melancholy. Cast also includes Mary Kay Place, Charlie Sheen and Orson Bean.

results.title: Being in: Life Be In It
results.brief_description: Examines the ‘Life Be In It’ campaign, its progress and the continued support it needs form members of the community, and advocates ways of becoming a part of the program. The ‘Life Be In It’ campaign was aimed at fostering community involvement in physical recreation, physical fitness and healthier lifestyles for all Australian.
